p: Influenza is a major global health concern that accounts annually for tens of thousands of deaths in North America [ 1, 2] and approximately 400,000 deaths worldwide [ 3]. Much effort has been invested in mathematical modeling of influenza dynamics in order to design improved control strategies [ 4, 5] and to estimate their economic impacts [ 6]. A fundamental limitation of such studies is a lack of quantitative information concerning the relationships between influenza infection and health care system utilization. In particular, how should we expect changes in influenza transmission dynamics induced by control measures [ 5, 7, 8] to translate into (i) changes in influenza-associated visits to physiciansâ€™ offices or hospitals and (ii) health care system burdens from influenza-associated hospitalizations?
